articles.description: Some additional details about the website

articles.title: About me
articles.contents:
My name is Jens, and my primary interests are within political
economy with a focus on the nexus between finance, economic development
and migration. Below is a sample of some of my work that used
 where I investigated how the process of
economic development affected emigration incentives. To see more, click
on the blog tab where I elaborate more on it.

articles.title: Migration and economic development
articles.description: Using data from the World Bank, this article examines the historical relationship between economic development and emigration from the period 1960-2000
articles.contents:
Introduction
This article explores the relationship between economic development
emigration rates ina historical perspective. Classical economic theories
suggest that there is a linear relationship between economic development
and emigration and as countries move from low-income to high-income,
their emigration rates should fall concomitantly. However, there is much
data to support that this theoretical relationship doesn’t hold. Rather,
the relationship between emigration rates and economic development seems
to display an inverted U-shape. Such a relationship was first put
forward by Wilbur Zelensky in 1971 and thus posits that middle-income
countries display the highest emigration rates.
To explore this relationship further, this article draws on data on
emigration stocks form the World
Bank Data Bank as well as the Penn World
Tables version 10.0. To be amenable to visualization, methods using
statistical programming for aggregation and data wrangling was employed
and finally using ggplot2 and plotly to create the interactive graphs
seen below. The complete methodology can be found here[link].
The article is a further examination of the empirical work undertaken
by Michael Clemens in his article “Does development reduce
migration? (2014)” and will suggest that while emigration and
economic development does seem to display an inverted U-shape, the data
seems to suggest that the factor of political economy plays a
significant role in shaping and driving the mobility transition rather
than just economic development in and of itself.
Theory and methodology
